Posts.Title: Please pray for my cousin vickib VickiSam

Posts.Content: JMEH31854 wrote: I'm looking for anyone who was diagnosed with DCIS only and then over time a tumor showed up outside the breast. My oncologist says there aren't a lot of us in the country. I had a mastectomy and radiation in 1998 because of DCIS. This was followed by 11 uneventful years with no recurrence in the chest wall or other breast. In 2009, an x-ray showed a large tumor on my R femur. Another was found in my lung. I seem to fall between standard protocols because I'm taking Herceptin, but have never taken systemic chemo. I'd like to hear about the experiences of others who skipped over Stages I-III. Thanks. JMEH31854 Dx 2/18/2011, IDC, Stage IV, ER+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 12:06AM JMEH31854 wrote: I don't believe I'm BRCA1 or 2 positive because I don't have any close relatives that have had breast cancer. I'm the only one at this point...and I'm the baby. But I haven't been tested.

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 06:16PM JMEH31854 wrote: So there are a few us! And my onc made it clear at my fist visit in 2009 that the two tumors wouldn't be BC if the pathology report from '98 was accurate. But BC was a good diagnosis as recurrences for bone and lung (my mets sites) are usually around 18-24 months. Alas, my bone scan last Friday showed a new mets on my other femur and I'll be getting rads for the 3rd time. I'm coming to terms that my life will have other "bumps in the road" or as my college son called it, "disconcerting" events. But God has blessed me over and over and over again, so I know that this recent event will lead to more opportunities to get to know Him better, or that amazing moment when I will see Him face to face. I expect the face-to-face is down the road a ways. I'm also on Zometa and Arimedix. Never took Tamoxifen. Hard to believe I'm at the 13-year mark hand have never lost my hair! Thanks to you both for letting me know I'm not alone.
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 06:39PM JMEH31854 wrote: Thank for linking me up with RivkA Matitya's blog! Surprised doctors, statistical anomaly's...I just say that my cells weren't listening to the pathologist!
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 01:43AM - edited Feb 25, 2011 01:45AM by JMEH31854 Thanks for all the comments on this topic. I don't feel alone anymore. My rad onc said that, yes, DCIS to mets may be from a microinvasion that was not caught; but it also may be a new case, that isn't caught when it's still in the chest wall. He stressed that knowing exactly what happened is less important than making good treatment decisions with what we do know to improve my quality of life and length of life. In 1998, there wasn't a protocol for radiation treatment for DCIS with dirty margins. My rad onc called two doctors out East. One didn't irradiate and had seen DCIS come back in the chest wall. The other did irradiate and hadn't seen it come back. Because of these reports, I did get radiation. I'm glad there are now protocols in place to treat dirty margins. I was fighting for radiation when I had no health insurance. Knowing that <10% of those of us who are diagnosed with DCIS will go directly to Stage IV is comforting, especially considering 1 in 8 women get BC. Let's face it, fixing a car is a more exacting science than medicine! While I took the fast train to Stage IV, I also skipped the treatments for Stages I-III. Each recurrence is a reminder that my life is not my own and an opportunity to recheck that I'm living my life to glorify the One who created me. Life is very good!
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 12:23PM JMEH31854 wrote: To Niecee24 and mari55 and others: It looks like it varies a lot as to how much time between when we are diagnosed as having DCIS before we hear Stage IV. I had 11 uneventful years. And I think of my friend's mom who was diagnosed with Stage IV pancreatic cancer and died exactly one month later. It seems like BC is not the worst news in the world considering the many treatment options and length of survival for many of us. Not to say it doesn't have it's hard moments or that some are not as fortunate, but many cancers indicate a much shorter length of life (on average). Every day is a day to rejoice and celebrate life!
